awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research in DRMS: Eating with your Heart on your Fork:  The role of affective processes in nudging dietary behavior.
awd_abstract_narration:
Obesity rates continue to rise, despite increased funding for nutrition education and policies to encourage healthy choices. This project addresses the question of how to get consumers to make healthier food choices without asking them to work hard to do so.  Finding answers to this question may be the key to reducing the obesity epidemic. The proposed research harnesses concepts from behavioral economics to make the healthy option the salient and easy choice. The filed experiments in this project offer an opportunity to study customers making decisions with real dietary consequences. The studies focus on consumption of French fries, soda, and desserts. The results can be extrapolated to other foods and applied to encouraging or discouraging a variety of dietary choices. From an economic standpoint, in addition to promoting health, the interventions could allow for-profit establishments to make more money by offering a smaller portion of a food item but still garner customer satisfaction.  

The objective of this project is to examine the role psychological processes (affective versus cognitive) play in making food choices.  Using novel methodologies that include acquiring individual level data on customer transactions, the research will investigate interventions to nudge people toward making healthy food choices. The project entails two field studies, both to be conducted within the foodservice operation of a large public university. The two studies focus on manipulations to decrease portion sizes of indulgent foods by appealing to emotional (affective processing) or non-emotional (cognitive) motives. The aim of the first study is to compare a charity/pro-social motive (tapping a hypothesized emotional mechanism) to a nutrition/self-interest motive (tapping a hypothesized cognitive mechanism) in their effectiveness in nudging college students to downsize their French fry portion and/or accept fountain water instead of soda. The aim of the second study is to examine whether manipulating menu descriptions can impact satisfaction with food consumed.  The researchers predict that a sensory-rich, detailed (emotional) description of a dessert can, in effect, substitute for size of the dessert, making diners just as satisfied with a small portion of dessert as they would with a larger portion of the same dessert, absent the decadent, emotionally-detailed description.  Both studies will test the "emotion effect" in getting individuals to eat less while feeling virtuous and satisfied with smaller portions.

por.por_cntn:
Peggy Policastro has completed Doctoral Dissertation Research in DRMS: Eating with your Heart on your Fork: The role of affective processes in nudging dietary behavior supported by a NSF
Dissertation Grant. During the funding period, she completed two independent field studies, testing manipulations that harnessed the principles of Behavioral Economics to encourage the choice of water over sugar sweetened beverages (SSBs) (Study 1) and to promote acceptance of a smaller portion size of a decadent dessert (Study 2). Each study tested a novel intervention to promote a healthier beverage/food choice.  

For Study 1, Policastro examined the effects of two types of nudges— a self-interest calorie labeling intervention and a pro-social charity incentive —and a combination of both, on college students’ choice of fountain water over SSB when purchasing a prix-fixe meal in a university dining operation. The calorie message encouraged students to consider the calorie and sugar savings that would result from choosing water over SSB. The charity message offered to donate the cost savings between the beverages to a local hunger focused charity. In the combination intervention, both the calorie savings and charity messages were displayed. In the original grant proposal, we predicted that the charity message would be more effective in increasing water sales and decreasing SSB sales; however, the results revealed the opposite effect. The calorie message was effective and the charity message had no impact on increasing water sales.

Policastro traveled to San Diego, CA. to present the findings of Study 1 at an oral poster session entitled: Drinking with Your Heart on Your Straw: Nudges to Entice Patrons to Choose Water over Soda at the 2016 Society of Nutrition Education and Behavior National Conference. A manuscript entitled: Targeted Calorie Message Promotes Healthy Beverage Consumption Better than Charity Incentive was prepared, submitted to the Obesity journal and accepted for publication after multiple revisions. The article will be published in 2017. 

In field Study 2, she examined whether diners are more satisfied with a smaller portion of a decedent dessert when a sensory-rich description of the item is present versus a nutritional description of the dessert. She hypothesized that that the sensory-rich description would increase satisfaction with the small portion size because it enhances the affective experience of consumption. The results indicated that the sensory description made participants less sensitive to the serving size. Shown a sensory rich description of a decadent dessert, participants ate similar portions of large and small pieces of cake, they were willing to pay the same amount for a large and small piece of cake, and feel similarly full after eating small and large pieces of cake.  Sensory descriptions can substitute for size.  However, a nutrition description enhanced or maintained the response to the cake size in that participants ate a smaller proportion of a large than small piece of cake and they were willing to pay more for a large than small piece of cake. Calorie labels could prompt restraint if offering a large portion size of a decadent item. The findings of the study suggest that if offering a small piece of a dessert, provide a sensory description and if offering a large piece of dessert, provide nutrition information as it may discourage eating the whole portion.

 

 

Policastro traveled to British Columbia, Canada to present the findings of the Study 2 at the 2017 International Society of Behavioral Nutrition and Physical Activity Conference at an oral session entitled: Tasting With Your Eyes: Sensory Description Substitutes for Portion Size. Policastro will continue to write a manuscript for publication detailing the research process, results and outcomes of Study 2.

Study 1 was included in Peggy Policastro’s doctoral dissertation.  Study 2 was not completed in time to be included in the dissertation.

The ability to receive this grant for a doctoral dissertation has allowed Policastro to hone her skills as a researcher to garner a position in the New Jersey Institute for Food, Nutrition and Health at Rutgers University where she will be conducting research in the area of Behavioral Nutrition.
